ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Bronco Wine Company is a family owned / operated business that produces a variety of wines. Bronco Wine Company has prided itself in ensuring a safe operation dating back to startup of the company in 1974.

Bronco Wine Company's Human Resource Manager and Safety Manager are personally committed to offer superior service and to maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The Safety Manager administers the company's safety and environmental policies. He is also responsible for various inspections to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs.  These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, confined space entry, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

Bronco Wine Company has an emergency response plan in effect.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.)  To save lives.
2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.)  To protect the environment.
4.)  To minimize property damage.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Bronco Wine Company is located at 6342 Bystrum Avenue, in Ceres, California.  The facility is situated on 80 acres in a rural area located off of Keyes Road which is approximately 5 miles south from Highway 99 on Crows Landing Road.   The majority of the ammonia equipment is located outside throughout the facility.  The one-ton containers of sulfur dioxide are located outside in the crush area; however, the smaller cylinders are used throughout the plant. The facility was originally built in 1974.

AMMONIA
The low side of the refrigeration system typically uses one or more evaporators to re

move heat from the space or products to be cooled.  An evaporator contains a set of continuous coils through which the refrigerant flows.  Due to the low pressures and corresponding low temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant quickly evaporates, absorbing a great deal of heat from the surrounding area.  To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia.

The low and high sides of the refrigeration system are separated by the compressor and the expansion valve.  The compressor is the driving force of the system.  It pulls refrigerant vapor from the evaporator (low side) at a rate that will maintain the evaporator pressure required for the desired operating temperature.  At the same time it pressurizes the warm vapor and forces it into the condenser and the high side of the system.  Refrigeration compressors on the market today are screw type, reciprocating, and centrifugal.  

Expansion valves regulate the flow of liquid refrigerant from the high side to the low side by causing a large pressure drop.  These valves are located between the receiver (high side) and the evaporator (low side).  This valve, coupled with the capacities of the compressor, can help regulate the pressure of the evaporator thereby creating the cooling capabilities of the system.  The high side of the refrigeration system consists of a condenser and a receiver.  Warm refrigerant vapor enters the condenser after it has been pressurized by the compressor.  A condenser will typically use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser.  As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from this vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the receiver.  The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side.  It also serves to hold the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not op

erating.

The Bronco Wine Company ammonia systems are utilized in two processes that are connected and co-located:  Champagne and Main. Bronco Wine Company's two ammonia refrigeration systems are closed systems that cycle the refrigerant, or ammonia, from liquid to gas and back again.  The systems, consisting of piping, valves, and process equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for product and process equipment. 

Changes in pressure are directly related to changes in temperature: lowering the ammonia pressure lowers its temperature.  Low pressure (cold) liquid ammonia provides refrigeration by removing ambient heat.  Removal of ambient heat causes the liquid ammonia (contained within the system) to vaporize.  Heat is later removed from the ammonia as it is condensed back into a liquid.  Typical operating conditions range from approximately 27 psig on the low pressure side of each system to 200 psig on the high side.  

The maximum intended inventory of ammonia is of 250,000 pounds.

SULFUR DIOXIDE
Sulfur dioxide is used in the crush process.  Sulfur dioxide from a one-ton container is pushed, using house nitrogen at approximately 80 psi, through a flexible line to a filter.  Downstream of the filter, the sulfur dioxide flows through a rotameter, a solenoid valve, and into the crusher.  The pipeline is filled with sulfur dioxide up to the solenoid valve.  At this point, the flow is dependent on the demand at the crusher.  When the pump at the crusher is turned on, the solenoid valve opens allowing the flow of sulfur dioxide into the crusher unit.

The maximum intended inventory of sulfur dioxide is five one ton containers or 16,000 pounds. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Administrative Measures
The facility operates in accordance with International

Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards as well as practices taught by the Refrigeration Engineers and Technicians Association. 

Engineering Measures
The ammonia refrigeration systems are equipped with various automatic process controls which ensure safe and efficient operation of the compressors, condensers, chillers, jacketed tanks, pump package, suction traps, and solenoid valves.  In addition, pressure relief valves automatically engage in the event of overpressurization.

The refrigeration systems are equipped with various status indicators to monitor system parameters and to minimize the potential for ammonia-related accidents.  The monitoring systems consist of 1) indicators (pressure, temperature, and level), 2) alarms (pressure, temperature, and level), and 3) routine inspections.  Pressure/temperature indicators are located throughout the system.  Level indicators, such as a sight glass, are located on vessels maintaining a liquid level (e.g. high pressure receiver and the pump package vessel).  System alarms are activated at the control panel.

In addition, operations are monitored through routine system inspections conducted by qualified operators and mechanics.  Operators are always on-site during times of system operation.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Based on a review of the Hazard Assessment Update (May 2004), the five year accident history (May 1999 through May 2004) revealed that there were two minor incidents involving sulfur dioxide and one involving ammonia; however, there were no injuries or off site property damage associated with these scenarios. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The following summarizes the emergency response and notification procedures at the facility.  

1.In the event of a spill, release, near miss, or threatened release involving ammonia, evacuate the immediate area and report the situation to the area supervisor.  If appropriate, hit the system emergency stop button.

2.Area supervisor will conta

ct the Plant Manager and the Chief Engineer.  If both are not available (e.g. off-site), then the highest ranking supervisor on-site is contacted at the front office.  If needed, the Plant Manager and Chief Engineer are contacted using pagers and/or telephone calls.

3.When the evacuation alarm sounds, all employees should follow the evacuation procedures and evacuate the plant to ensure their safety. Currently, the facility evacuates its employees by the use of an alarm system and personal communication.  It is the responsibility of the management and supervisory staff to notify all employees of the need to evacuate.

4.Call 911 to ensure public safety.  The Chief Engineer or his designated alternate will evaluate the situation and determine appropriate response measures (e.g. use remote emergency switch to shut down equipment, clean up spills, etc.).

5.Notify the Stanislaus County Department of Environmental Resources, Hazardous Materials Division 

6.If more than 100 pounds of ammonia or 500 pounds of sulfur dioxide is released within a 24 hour period, the National Response Center  should be notified immediately.

7. If serious injuries or harmful exposures to workers occurs, call the nearest Cal/OSHA field office.

8. Within 48 hours, a complete investigation must be performed.

9. Within 30 days of the release, the Emergency Release Follow-up Notice Reporting Form must be completed and sent to the Chemical Emergency Planning and Response Center (CEPRC) Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) in Sacramento.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Bronco Wine Company has conducted a PSM/RMP Compliance Audit (January 2004) and revalidated the Process Hazard Analysis (May 2001). Both studies resulted in minor procedural modifications to ensure a safe operation. These modifications are currently being implemented with an expected date of completion being December 1, 2004. The Safety Manager and the Human Resources Manager are responsible for ensuring that these r

ecommendations are implemented. 

In addition to the mitigation measures included in the Compliance Audit and Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation, the Process Safety Management team continues to ensure employee involvement in Safety Plan Development and training requirement protocol.
